checkpoints.event: Train leaves Fort William. The ScotRail guard lady is competing for entertainment points with expressly paid entertainers on the steam train which will leave half an hour after us
Train enters the Glenfinnan Viaduct. An extortionate amount of people wave at us from all around
Walk begins from Glenfinnan station, except that somebody trusts Google Maps over physical wooden signs and almost runs us into a stone wall
We stop in a strategic location with view of the viaduct and wait for the steam train
Steam train passes and receives great pomp
We set off for the Glenfinnan monument
We reach the visitor centre where the loo queue is 25 minutes long
We reach the monument
Lunch on the side of the short edge of Loch Shiel
Lunch ends
We set off for the viaduct again, to observe the other (returning) steam train from a different angle
We're all set and waiting
A plume of steam can be observed over the inferred location of Glenfinnan station
Steam train passes

Some Chinese visitors to our right shoot some footage from a drone, despite signs at the visitor centre and along the path having clearly indicated the forbiddenment of drones, going so far as to crucify-pin a couple on the wooden post (although I don't understand the reason for this forbiddenment)
We make our way back down
We encounter the Chinese visitors again; while attempting to take a drone selfie over the water, the guy pilots it into a tree and crashes it into the ground.
Dev: That was more satisfying than the train going over the viaduct!

We try to investigate another path, which takes us to a field where multiple levels of professional filming are taking place, with tripods and a (much beefier and I suppose authorised) drone; but the field dead-ends, leaving us with a choice of returning to the bridge or trying to cross the river Finnan some other way
Failed attempted river crossing by jumping from stone to stone

Successful reattempted river crossing by jumping from stone to stone, just by me; random strangers congratulate me for the feat and I think two girls were filming me so if you see me on Youtube please file for a community strike
Back at the visitor centre, the loo queue isn't 25 minutes long anymore
Path to another viewpoint
We return to the station via the A road
Walk ends at Glenfinnan station, whence trains will come and leave in both directions at once
We go over the viaduct once more
Walk begins
First public toilet
Fourth public toilet (because it wasn't even counted!)
The patterns and drawings etched into the concrete of a beach hut array
Dispatch
Hurst castle and lunch
Lunch ends-ish
Weeavetne vicinity of the castle
End of shingle; ice cream truck
Second (counted) public toilet
We stare intently at boats we'll never have the intention to afford
Walk ends in Lymington old town
The much advertised chips aren't so overwhelming
I love it when this happens!

accounts.what: There are 3 public toilets along today's walk, which is an extremely rare occurrence.

name: Corfe Castle walk and camping intro

checkpoints.event: We get off the train at Wareham and a whole array of faff ensues while we sort out groups and stuff
When Serena shows up, that makes 14 of us in Will's group. There are about 20 people in James's group. The same circuit will be done in opposite directions by the two groups
Walk(s) start(s)

Thomas explains the 3 or so layers of this organisational onion: there are people who drove to the walk and will further drive to the campsite with a lot of everyone's camping stuff, who will stay there until Monday; there are people driving there but returning tomorrow; and there are people on the walk who won't have space in the car so will take the train to Moreton and walk. Oh, and there are the cyclists who will be useless for carrying stuff
An exodus of biscuits-break
Impassable A road
Thomas experiments his invincible water filter-pump on some really dodgy mud puddle
Thomas: Tastes like sweet potatoes.
We reach Corfe Castle and split based on interest; a few people with National Trust passes go to the castle itself
Lunch break at the official picnic spot
Lunch break ends
Ice cream shop
Thomas is late to the meeting point and time!
Someone: Maybe he found something interesting inside.
New Will: Maybe he found water!
Walk resumes by such a way that will likely bypass the other group
That may be them on top of that hill
Thomas: We appear to have walked into a dead end
Cows are escaping!
Will made a navigational mistake and we'll forever remember
Pass the entrance to Blue Pool again
Break
Actually, we return to the road because the experimental path ahead is too boggy
Thomas: I will take responsibility for anyone who feels grief for walking back this way.
Walk ends at the bridge where kids are jumping into the clearly too shallow water, but somehow survive
We then wait for a long time at the entrance to Sainsbury's where some of the campers buy what they'll need
We then go to the King's Arms for dinner but it's too early and the food offering is underwhelming, so we stick to drinks
We get dinner from explicit & implicit fish & chips shops
At some point James and Matt D. from the other group join us. We gather on the grass on the side of river Frome, opposite the posh pub, to eat
but we're late to the 19:10 universal gathering of both groups!
Anyway the leaders of the organisation coordinate somehow and we set off. Almost everyone from Will's group is going to the campsite and we have enough room to give lifts; I end up in Shaun's car

We get turned around in the village of Affpuddle because the pin where Google Maps thinks the campsite is is uselessly inaccurate. While figuring out the way with Serena's OS Maps app, we encounter Byron on a bike
The path from the main road to the actual section of forest ascribed to us is very treacherous. We are the first of the day-walkers to arrive; we find Mahmoud and Kate at the campsite
We light a fire
At some point the others with cars arrive, and later those who took the train to Moreton
James blows up his massive blow-up mattress – he basically brought a bed to camp

I'm not a gatecrasher, so as planned and advertised, I leave the campsite and embark on the most dangerous thing I've done this year, which is the adventure of finding my way to Moreton station, alone, at night
This is a real forest with real animal noises. I feel uneasy
25 minutes of very brisk walking later, I reach the main road

A misleading signpost points to Moreton village centre off to the left instead of Moreton station. Although I know the path is dead straight, I doubt myself and attempt to look it up. There is no signal. My phone dies. There is no light left in the sky. I feel very uneasy
I reach Moreton station with 28 minutes to spare (which I can't kill on my phone because it's dead! So I write this final log line on the train ticket)
Due to the GWR we took between Southampton and Salisbury being delayed by just enough we have to wait almost an hour in Salisbury for the connection; some of us take a pre-walk false walk
False walk begins
False walk ends
We're on the train again
Walk begins
Mandatory encounter with cows (first of many)

That tractor speaks train! Or… oops? The farmer driving it is trying to get our attention and shouts at us across a large field, probably to tell us not to walk where we're walking, but we can't understand (and it's a public footpath!)
A number of farm and other vehicles, and us, meet on this narrow road. I know I said this before but this zone really is heavily farm-industrial
We reach Charlton Horethorne where we stop for lunch
Lunch ends
Camelot story time
Sign: Sherborne 6
We split into a group of 7 (led by Tom D.) who will do the full (long) walk, and a group of 4 (led by James) who will take a shortcut
James: 15 minutes into the pub!
The other party are 3k “that way”
We reach Sherborne
Walk ends at Half Moon pub
While waiting for food and stuff we find out by internet-powered comms that there's a long-long and a long-short group; the latter aiming to catch the 19:37 train
James leaves to get the train, while the rest of us are enjoying our full meals and have conceptually exchanged an extra hour for an extra pint
James and Matt D (re)appear into the pub! We learn that Will is the only one who caught the 19:37 train
After James and Matt D devour their meals, we leave the pub and meet the others (bar Will) at Sherborne station
Questions about barricaded double lines, at Tisbury
Passing Bournemouth, there is one hillwalker on the train
Passing Southampton Central, there are now 3 hillwalkers on the train
Guard (sees my ticket): Oh, that's a bizarre place to go!
Guard (sees Tom's ticket): Botley is very popular today!
Passing Southampton Airport, there are now 7 hillwalkers on the train
Tom: What are [the freight trains] loading from here?
Me: Could it have to do with all those carefully segregated piles of sand?
Tom: What, is it some Eastleigh speciality sand?
Walk begins
Why is this country lane so busy‽
I hit my head on a low branch
We make it past quite muddy a stretch of path, but historical data suggests it could have been (and indeed has been, last year) much worse
Welcome to Bishop's Waltham
We reach Bishop's Waltham Palace and Tom gives us a guided tour
Lunch
We visit the small local museum
Car park with toilets and female guitarist
Gentlemen, we lost the ladies!
Yes, Ben, we're in the South Downs
Playground
We leave the playground
We approach a low-hanging branch
James: Watch your heads!
Me: I'll forget by the time I get there!
James waits for me to come closer.
Me: I appreciate you waiting to tell me again.
James: Watch your head, Teo!
I successfully avoid that branch, but the next one nicks my hat off.
Me: This is ridiculous!
Deer oh dear!

Walk ends at Hedge End station where two trains are stuck on the Eastleigh-bound line, the first one having broken down, so we go to the Fareham-bound platform to return via the other side of this rail triangle.
Walk begins
Donkeys to ride for £4
Nothe Fort
Eilish joins
Sandsfoot Castle
The path didn't exist
Begin crossing bridge to Portland
Lunch
That was quite a story! (St George's Church)
Statue quarry
Eilish leaves us
Walk ends
Walk starts
Bird observatory
Lunch
Somebody tell this corn field owner to define his paths!
Path to the circle of 9 stones dead-ends into a construction site
We reach Maiden Castle
This straight road we step on now is the final stretch yes
Walk ends

name: Windmill Hill aka Ridiculously Early in the Day Walk

checkpoints.event: Walk begins
A break
A tangled traffic situation with a farm vehicle
Steepest hill of the walk, just as the clouds decided to vanish and the wind to stop
The windmill!
Elevenzeens
“Under 2km to go now!”
Walk ends, but the train is at :22 so we go to a café where God sent a fan
Lunch in Havant, while observing an extortionate amount of Portsmouth-bound trains and a swift switcheroo of platforms in response to the stopper breaking down on the other platform
I guideline-abidingly tie a mask on my face and walk into Bournemouth station. The Southampton-Bournemouth pendulum-stopper has just pulled in.
It leaves one minute early!

Pulling into Brockenhurst, I notice that the platform 1 tracks, commonly used by the Poole stopping service, are rusty, proving they haven't been used in a long time. Then, 4 walkers join me on the train.
Tom greets us at the exit gate from Beaulieu Road station, with 8 further walkers waiting in a green area down the road
Walk begins
They found a pony
We found deer
Walk ends in Brockenhurst at a pub we don't enter
I start cycling to Rhys's block
I enter Rhys's garage and begin to pump up my tyres with his pump which is superior to mine
We set off towards Branksome station
We arrive at Branksome station and buy one-way tickets
We board a train to Wool
We get off the train and start our cycle to the coast
Flippin heck now on this steep descent into Lulworth is not the time and place for blinding wind!
We arrive at the Visitor Centre and tie our bikes to the wooden, insecure-looking, but perfectly solid fence
Walk begins

At the crosspaths with the Durdle Door beach path and the caravan park path, we take the overcliff path as the main path to the beach has been made exit-only; while there are only 4 other people anywhere in sight and therefore this fact is irrelevant, a coastguard helicopter hovering above the arch is intimidating us very much from going against the signage
Having walked the expected loop we unexpectedly descend to the beach without the arch because the arch isn't cool anymore
Lunch begins
Lunch ends
Some interestingly coloured rocks are observed at the end of the beach
We follow a path along the caravan park, which is nice initially but later forces us to walk along an asphalt road
Walk ends
Main cycle begins

As we stop on a high street in Wareham to catch our breaths and have water, an old almost-certainly-homeless man starts a conversation in which he doesn't listen to us and complains about how people don't listen nowadays
Main cycle ends by the ferris wheel by Bournemouth Pier
Walk begins
Walk happens

It's the first time I hear this kind of announcement: “The next bus to depart from -- outside the station at platform 2 -- is the 12:25 South Western Railway service to Southampton Central. Calling at Southampton Central only.”
The replacement bus (actually a coach) leaves 2 seconds early!
The coach driver turns on the radio in the whole coach on BBC Radio 2. Also, it's bloody hot in here.
I take my own personal lunch break
The coach arrives in Southampton 2 minutes early!
Having seen no familiar faces on the platform, I board the train for Ashurst at the back of coach 4
I get off the train and run into Tom who takes me and a few others who actually were on the train to the pub where we meet the serious people who have walked 24km so far
The live rail shoe of these new(er) coaches is is totally shorting with the ground rail in the leaning curve of the station as the train departs :O
We leave the pub
We leave the yard of the pub, with 22 people and cross the footbridge in Ashurst station but as we do James decides not to do the latter half of the walk so we're left with 21 people
Bogs!
Passing Beaulieu Road; break at ⅔ of the whole way and group photo
The gate's been padlocked so we're climbing over it
Break
It's dark and animals are howling which I'm pretty sure you don't hear howling during the day
Bogs in the dark!
Walk ends outside Lymington station where we meet James again and some people leave for the immediate next train
We hit the Six Bells Wetherspoons

accounts.what: This walk has set a new record for the amount of skipping in this club!

Why didn't we think of bringing a portable speaker on a walk before?! We only had the away trips, or other minibus-powered events, to experience a playlist. I think Will surpassed all other social secretaries I know with this idea.

checkpoints.event: I bump into Noah on the Northern line
We run into Thomas at a shop in Euston station, then soon into a lot of others
Caledonian Sleeper leaves, as planned
We get off the Caledonian Sleeper. It's so desolate and quiet! Even the train leaving is quiet.
Thomas and the back lot are having a conference on the road
We reach the hostel
Breakfast & walks organisation
Thomas heads for the station to retrieve more people
Simon, Mahmoud etc head for the mountainous walk
Jenny etc (“we”) head for the loch walk – anticlockwise
Thomas retrieves later train arrivers and brings them to the hostel
Simon abandons his group with a view to hijack our loch walk
Thomas etc leave hostel heading clockwise around the loch
We reach some posh accommodation-y buildings
Top of the loch (map-wise)
Lunch at a lochside hut locked on one side but open on the other
Simon catches up
Lunch break ends
The wind is shooting bits of ice into our faces!
We reach bridge over stream at near side of loch
Mahmoud etc radio in saying everything is going to plan; much stronger wind can be heard from their side
We return to the hostel
Radio contact
Noah appears
Briefing from Tom the hostel master
Mahmoud etc return
Game of Pun Intended
We begin to cook
Ongoing arguments about salt
Food served
Thomas etc go to the station to pick up the most late arrivers
Thomas etc return with only Krzysztof!
We sleep
We wake up and eat
Thomas goes to the station for the nth time and returns with the mostest latest arrivers
Walks organisation
Thomas etc head for mountainous walk
Simon, Jenny etc (“we”) head for the Simon Walk, with some lodge ruins as destination
We can see the lodge we're heading to in the distance
And now if you look back you can see Corrour station!

As a train passes we realise we were looking at the wrong lodge. Sorry, not wrong – just different to the one on the map; this one is close to the railway. Well it's technically on the way to the correct lodge :|
The most leap-of-faith-y bridge in the county
We reach said wrong lodge and have lunch in the slight shelter offered by its ceilingless walls
We leave aiming to walk via saddle, by river which implies boggy lands
Water everywhere and lands too boggy for the average footwear, so we decide to turn back the way we came, hence doing the Discount Simon Walk after all
We're at a stone's throw from the hostel and I decide to take a detour via the station to use the WiFi

I'm at the station downloading all the latest messages and memes and two cyclists genuinely waiting for the train appear and start offering me food because I must be looking like a drenched hobo or something
The latest memes are daft and I leave
I'm back at the hostel
Radio contact from Thomas etc who say to be an hour away
Game of Cards Against Humanity with explanations of every word and phrase by Matt Thesaurus; makes me ponder how we get to know so many dirties which sound so cringy when “taught”
Thomas etc return
We eat
We really eat
I go to sleep and everybody else seems to have already done so
Lights on
Iceberg on the loch
It's snowing horizontally and Mahmoud & Harry leave for the mountainous walk
Noah heads off on his own
Simon etc (“we”) leave for a peak, followed by Thomas etc a few minutes later
We have begun a steep ascent for a few minutes and it's difficult because the snow is randomly deep; otoh the rocky cliff shields us from the wind

We reach summit and meet Thomas etc who overtook us by climbing the other side of the peak. Their path was of more constant difficulty whereas ours was easy then hard. Wind! My sense of verticality is destroyed
Noah returns to the hostel
We decide which way to descend
We begin the descent
Back at the hostel
Thomas etc return to hostel
Some start leaving for the station
We all leave for the station
I reach the station but a stupid hail storm has been hitting my face for the past half hour and there's literally frozen snow all over my coat so don't even talk to me I hate everything
The train!
Many thanks to the person who left a half-full bottle of real fruit juice on the train table
Also thanks to the lady on the train who suggested that we go to Cobb's pub near Fort William station, wherein I am now sipping out of a bottle of Newcastle
Seeing that the others are planning to stay in the pub for another half an hour, I head out for a stroll because clearly I haven't had enough walking over the past three days

I've only been in Fort William for 5 minutes and I already agree with the people who hate the recently built dual carriageway because I'd prefer to be able to walk along the water without jumping over fences which are clearly there not to be jumped over
I walk around the outside of the Old Fort. Unfortunately there is no way back to street level on that side so I have to walk back round again
I return to the pub
We board the Caledonian Sleeper
Mahmoud & Harry join us on the Caledonian Sleeper
We waste time in Garelochhead because there's a flood up ahead and the driver is waiting for it to dry out I guess?
Me (walking out of Waterloo tube): Shit, I'm gonna miss the 8:35 I have advance ticket for!
Announcer: The 8:35 […] is delayed due to fallen trees. We apologise for the inconvenience.
Me: Oh, no, not at all – I thank you for the convenience!
Walk begins
Immediate toilet stop
We're lost
We're split
They're lost
We are whole
The Gun Inn – parking & toilets
Bridge
Lunch
Back to the Gun Inn
Bogs!
Walk ends at the Six Bells
Walk begins
Lansdowne
East Cliff beach
There are two piers. Not just at 10:41; there are always two piers.
Boscombe Pier, and wait for a few people from one train later to catch up
Portman Ravine
Lunch in the windiest clifftop imaginable
Walk ends
Walk begins
In-city orientation is not our strong suit, underpass reports
At the cathedral we realise we came to the cathedral for nothing, since the people we were hoping to meet here aren't here
We meet 3 more people at Cart&Horses (after 2km)
We wait for 4 more people to join us in an anonymous place with a most (in)secure shed door at the street corner
But then we leave anyway
At some point we acquire the extra people somehow
We meet and exchange map information with two people from Winchester Ramblers
Lunch near nice but closed church
OMG so much clay!
At some point we acquire Nick
John claims we have 2.5 hrs to go, while Thomas says only 1.5
Walk basically ends (intersection in Winchester) so by this measurement Thomas was less wrong
Walk really ends (Wetherspoons) so by this measurement John was less wrong
Walk begins
Swans
More swans
Dead squirrel
Halfway point of the south loop
End of main loop (10km) at cathedral structure and supposedly lunch break / visit time
9 people (both day walk secretaries included) are mental/brave/determined enough to proceed with the second half of the walk
The other 9 people have gone to the station and I'm sitting in Wetherspoons, where they have the audacity to have run out of beef burgers
Walk begins
We discover that Matt D. missed the start and wants to catch up with us, but upon catching up he decides against joining the walk
Middle of Itchen Bridge
Netley Abbey ruins
Group photo outside Netley Abbey ruins
Leave Netley Abbey ruins
Lunch break – the earliest ever!
Lunch break ends
We've just come into Hamble
Tom D.: We are just north, on the map, of the “a” in “Mallards Moor”. We just crossed the little stream.
Walk ends and extroductory speech by Tom D. and Will
A big bag and a bigger box shuffle past Portswood Primary. Local school children report seeing a man beneath them, loaded with numerous knock-off bargain sleeping bags. They are quite heavy.
Most trip-goers are stood beneath the Shop canopy on Redbrick in heavy rain, waiting for a Minibus.
A Minibus arrives.
Another Minibus arrives and blocks off a G4S cash transfer driver.
Minibuses loaded. Sleeping bags thrown up to roof racks with increasing force allowing us to witness projectile motion. Trip-goers are given the choice of either a minibus or a rollercoaster.
Traffic on M3 avoided via the Matt Clark’s Home back route.

Stop at Bicester Outlet Village. No, sorry, the Tesco next door. Trip-goers experience Oxfordshire shopping at it’s finest. Music in the Unlucky Minibus changes from Nick’s Queen to Jenny’s Fake Abba. Music in the Terrifying Minibus is still Techno Hits (3 CD Collection), which will never seem to end.
Stop in Stoke on Trent, also at a Tesco. Stoke’s drivers are a menace. Anna attempts to make use of El Pres’s Driving License as ID - this is not successful as El Pres is not a twelve year old.
Newcastle Under Lyme has a few too many roundabouts. Serena (the disembodied GPS voice) reminds us to take the second exit straight on.

M6 Closed. Sudden diversion onto A6 causes chaos solved only by Tom Tom and MattNav working in harmony. Arrival at Truckhaven Carnforth. MattNav finds out the diesel pumps are a little too excitable and spray everywhere, turning jeans into branded Diesel jeans.

Terrifying Minibus goes on a ride through the Central Lakes. People of Ambleside watch a fully loaded bus career through the town at precisely 62mph: conveniently just the speed needed to avoid the local speed camera. Unlucky Minibus tootles up the M6, admiring the very dark non-views.
Near Keswick, both minibuses find the Racetrack of the A66. Jenny finds a ‘need for speed’.
Terrifying Minibus arrives at the postcode. Too bad the postcode is half a km down the wrong track, through a gate at an unfordable stream. Other minibus avoids issue by using a map.
Convoy arrives. Chaos of everyone choosing a room avoided by having to first find the room.
Everyone asleep?
Star gazers aren't asleep, they're busy trying long(er) exposures
With military precision, the early risers room of two wakes up.
Early risers room of *three (including two star gazers)
Breakfast. We have a lot of apple juice, and blueberry wheats. This is good. Cats!
The Delightful Duo set off to walk to Styhead Pass, up the wilderness that is upper Ennerdale.
Minibuses set off for Wasdale. Terrifying Bus takes a shortcut across the moors, Unlucky Bus goes via Sellafield for some extra scenery.
Both minibuses reach Wast Water separately, taking in Britain’s Favourite View.
Walkers leave Wasdale Head via very small church. Donations are given, probably propping up the village’s lucrative illegal painkiller trade.
Nice views.

Reach Styhead Pass where almost all the group wander down to the lake. Committee and drivers show commitment to the cause by staying put and avoiding the climb back up. Delicious Duo reappear, having descended off Great Gable.
Corridor route is neither flat, short nor inside. On the plus side, Scafell Pike is now visible. Team Command take this opportunity to let everyone know where they’re going.
Corridor route is flatter and shorter than other routes (an 18.1% slope: minibus friendly as per SimonSays standards)
“Where are we going?”
Bad Step = bum slide.
Big Rock Slide of Doom (surprisingly) doesn’t cause mass desertion. This is good, because up next is the Bigger Rock Slide of Doom.
Summit reached, in cloud.
Group picture!
El Pres. confuses the front by not sticking to plan... “Compasses cause panic” -El Pres (Before he got the title, Brighton, Feb. 2019).
A bit of rain? Group descends slowly. Some confusion at the front about which direction they were heading (could have been solved by the use of a compass...)
... Two hours of knee wrecking descent ...
Unlucky minibus rescued from Wasdale mud by Simon Says. Toilet stop.
Unlucky minibus gains its nickname by diving into a puddle, to avoid a herd of Herdewicks. Puddle actually genuine disguised WW1 trench. Minibus beached.
Terrifying Minibus discovers the predicament, leading to even more speedy return to the bunkhouse so it can return for a Rescue Mission.
AA Operator: “Wasdale?”

AA Man on the way. Spirits high inside beached bus, despite 15 degree tilt. Outside, short straws are drawn as everyone tries to avoid explaining situation to passers-by. First lot of trip-goers back at bunkhouse, trying desperately to find their food.
Bunkhouse crew have found their food.

Simon Says reaches beached bus for rescue mission, with mince pies. In October? Who cares? Valiant drivers Not Headless Nick and Jenny stay behind in the dark, prepared for a long wait. Rescued Trip-goers find themselves in the film ‘Speed’.
AA Man arrives with oversized truck. 10 minutes later, Unlucky Minibus is out.
Rescue Mission returns very hungry. Very hungry for anything that’s not sweets or snacks, that is.
Complaints about lack of seasoning in the unlucky bus's portion arise

All back at the bunkhouse. This is some cause for celebration, probably more of Anna’s wine. Nick reveals he has Camembert. Impromptu cheese social with all those still awake, helped along by all the dinner desserts we forgot about.
What happens if we throw everything on the table in the fire? We find out.
Early rising room realises it forgot to move into a different room the previous night.
Mountain Crew attempt to leave.
Mountain Crew still at the bunkhouse.
Mountain crew stuck on minibus roof-racks, not given permission to take off
Still there.
Gone? Maybe?
Minibuses loaded, convoy leaves after saying goodbye to each and every cat.
Intimately Scottish marshy grounds appear accompanied by lack-of-path and path-stream mergers, appreciation of waterproof boots occurs
Pulsar driver pulls over due to tailgating convoy.
A private quarry car park is given to us by the National Trust.
Red Pike summit reached inside a cloud, a passer-by hillwalker is encountered and advised that High Stile is to the west, yet, he goes east!
Buttermere Toilets. Non-mountain group given a choice of a lake circuit led by Simon Says and MattNav or a waterfall walk led by Jenny and El Pres.
Almost everyone goes for the lake circuit. :(
Mountain crew done taking pictures and having lunch, after appreciating greasy mossy rock
Waterfall group reaches Mountain Crew at big waterfall after following a visible non-path. Profile pictures taken by Byron Burger. Lunch!
Mountain crew are delayed by the emergence of El Pres et. al., and El Pres's quest to find the head of the waterfall
Lake crew finish circuit to discover stone skimming. An attempt is made to swim in the lake.
All back together for one big photo on Buttermere.
Toilet stop! MattNav suffers calamity of forgetting wallet and breaking compass within five minutes.
Both minibuses leave for Keswick, via Newlands Hause.
Road closed, so we head for Honister Pass. Minibuses look on in terror.
Promotional picture shots.
Unlucky minibus grinds to a halt on 25% gradient. Slow, careful reverse back while clutch burns.
Scent of burning arises with the approach of the unlucky minibus
Jenny gets minbus up the pass thanks to a run up and empty road.
Keswick has hills INSIDE the town??
Minibuses leave the Lakes via the routes they came in. Unlucky minibus now has limited clutch.
Rhader? Rheader? Rheadr? Unlucky Minibus stops at some Welsh sounding fuel stop with 10 pork pies.
Sunset!!
Wetherspoons stop in Preston, known for... a bus station? A bypass? Not really sure. Dismal place.
Leave Preston to motor down the M6 via Minibus Karaoke (again).
stop at Cherwell Valley. All completely tired by this point. Except drivers, of course! They’re fully awake.
Arrival at Glen Eyre. One minibus does a city centre shuttle, the other goes round Portswood.
Sleeping bags and Hilly return home.
Sleeping bags return home, apart from one which joined a mysteriously familiar orange jacket on Sirdar Mews detour
Minibuses all back.
Everyone home. Trip ends.

accounts.what: Notes by El Pres (and so naturally 100% accurate) with a select few shadow entries by Mahmoud A. Times approximate.

checkpoints.event: I take a train
7 Unofficial walkers take a train
I get off a train
7 unofficial walkers get off a train
Walk starts from Beaulieu Road, the least used train station in the county of Hampshire
Matt recognises a woman walking:
Charlie Thompson, coastal oceanographer
I've no idea if she recognised me or she just said “Hi” out of sheer New Forest friendliness
This group of 6 girls is the 3rd group of girls we've run into
Woodfidley Crossing
A man walking the other way with his family asks if we've seen a group of girls.
A strawberry break
Fifth group?? Poor man looking for “a group of girls walking”…
Campsite
Sixth group… and now they're interactive! Of course president Thomas is the best man to go to for map directions, whether the asker is a club member or not

We wanted to stop for lunch at the ford, thus having a Ford Fiesta; but it was full of people with children and dogs and bikes, tons of bikes; so we kept walking and stopped at a subsequent crossroads instead
Lunch break ends
A bit of a mush
Walk ends on a bridge on the edge of Lymington
My train departs Bournemouth as expected
Train arrives at Wool; I get off and discover 10 Fast Walkers who claim the minibus groups are late and even they could get to the Visitor Centre in time
I begin to cycle down A352
The scenic route I was attempting to go down turns out to be a private road so I turn back to the A352
As I turn right into the Visitor Centre, I hear a vehicle behind. It's a Susu minibus!
Harry (from the front passenger's seat): Hello, Teo!
Me: What a timing!
The other 2 minibuses arrive, and some people with cars, but of course no sign of the Fast Walkers
Opening speech by President Thomas and division of groups: John – long and tough route; Tom – medium route 1; Thomas – medium route 2, initially having 15 people (including me)
TIL Lulworth Cove is an effect of diffraction of sea waves 😮
Thomas: And there's a small arch; it's gonna be a bigger arch when it's older.
We run into a vast group of school kids. Thomas advises us, and the others over the radio, to steer clear.
Thomas: Is that our hillwalkers engulfed in school kids? (over radio) Shaun, you're being swallowed!
Shaun (shouts): Hillwalkers!!!
Second high peak (forgot to log the first 🙁). Just as I reach the top and the view opens, Tom's group are leaving.
Beacon. Just as Tom's group catches a last glimpse of ours before going over a hill
TIL The sand connection between Weymouth and the island of Portland has been created naturally by currents from the Atlantic pushing rocks and dropping them into shallower water 😮
Our lunch break starts; Tom's group have just finished theirs and split – some stay behind with us for the really shortest route
Lunch finished but we wait for the Fast Walkers (aka Train People)
But then we realise we'd misread their message and leave anyway
To wait for them at the next field boundary
Thomas recovers the 10 Fast Walkers (from what seems like a secret spacetime passage in the grass)
Thomas: I don't like caravan parks. They're very confusing!
But even more confusing than the paths inside the caravan park is our attempt at organising people between toilets, ice cream vans, shops, and the beach
I'm in the ocean so I totally can't be writing this 😛
Walk ends when John's group descend upon the beach
Obligatory group picture
Last bunch of us leave the beach

As the 09:24 from Southampton abruptly terminated in Bournemouth where it didn't exist at all as the 10:04 that it should have been, we are now waiting for a hopeful 10:45 on platform 4 – the place where trains go when they die.
Guard: We are waiting for driver for this train.
Guard: As soon as they let us know we'll let you know.
Guard: We have a driver en route to platform 4.
Harry: No one get off here! This is not where we get off!
And everyone remembered that time when walkers randomly exited the train in Poole.
Walk begins
Impressive tractor encounter
Someone left their keys in the door!
Sign: Beware! Clay shooting ahead
Thomas: Hello! Bench, bench, bench, choose a pick, we'll be here for about 20 minutes for lunch.
Lunch break ends
Maybe I should log the log to the log. (battle of twigs & logs)
R.V. W2 Caution Military traffic
Walk ends at the Ship Inn
We leave for the station
Barrier drops
Train leaves
A train leaves Southampton
Plan exposition. Walk begins
End of street lighting
Star/cloud observation stop
turned into biscuit break,
turned into coffee break
Pause for a few people to catch up and for Thomas to briefly activate the fairy lights turning his backpack into a Christmas tree. Discussion about off-shore wind energy farm visible in the distance
Chalk path approach warning. Discussion about anti-blister socks
Surprised people observe us from a settlement
Interesting Gloom on the horizon
Pause by big radio tower
Wind picks up
Longer official snack break where the wind calms down and from where a snaking motorway can be seen, as well as allegedly Gatwick airport in the far distance

Footpath hits a road with wooden indicator arrows reading: South Downs Way – River Adur 4½ mi (where we came from) / Brighton 5 mi / South Downs Way – Ditchling Beacon 15½ mi (where we're headed) / Poynings 1 mi
Halfway gate
We cross the A23
The gloomy Gloom on the horizon seems closer, and now an early-morning celestial body (Venus?) has risen right into the middle of the thing
What are windmills?
Something clicks the wrong way in my brain and I suddenly feel exhausted
The Gloom on the horizon is now more closely observed and thought to be coming from an object on the sea, which, though still unidentified, is dubbed a “party flotilla”
Pond of Reflection
We stop at a trig point to wait for the tail of the group. Climbing on it, we awfully disappointingly unequivocally conclude that the Gloom on the horizon is the stadium
Thomas: This is the highest point in Sussex.
Serena: West Sussex?
Thomas: […] We are now in East Sussex. We've crossed the border.
Harry: We're immigrants!
Thomas: And this is the highest point in both Sussexes. Sussexes?... Sussexi.
Discovered: Bus stop: High Park Corner. 79 towards Brighton station – Sunday & public holidays first bus 10:46
Crazy singing cyclist whizzes past
Joe: And the dawn chorus has arrived! Right on cue! Quarter to six!
Joe: I hear traffic!
Ditchling Road Bridge of great sunrise observation view
Serena: That is some thing!
Walk ends
A train leaves Brighton
One impossible train connection in Bournemouth estranges an amount of walkers from the main group
We seem to lose additional people… to unexplained actions.
Walk begins
One minute pause to ponder a ready-made Christmas tree next to a thatched roof house
Is that a path or a stream?
Thomas: So we're heading… that way! Through the stream that's a path!
Break for biscuits and map examination in order to reroute for bog avoidance
Top of hill, pile of rocks commemorating Mary Baxter
Harry: Ground Control to major Thomas, we are at the top of the hill.
Lunch break part 1, for people are hungry and it's almost not raining, but it's windy and cold nonetheless
A place of peace and tranquility
Corfe castle becomes visible
Group picture
We reach the village of Corfe castle and acquire 6 more people,
but are soon to lose 3 people
while Thomas explains that we have half an hour to explore the village
…but the model village is closed for the winter
With a 5-minute delay and after some rather dubious walkie talkie powered quarrel between female committee members, we proceed to walk again
Recoordination break – all is on track
It's getting dark…
…and darker…
…darkest.
“And at last I see the light…”
Serena: We're getting really close to the pub now.
Nick: I can smell the beer!
Road, bridge, and lights… civilisation
Walk ends
Instructions are given
Instructions finish to be given and teams disperse
Exactly one hour after I arrived on a CrossCountry train from Bournemouth, the next CrossCountry train can be observed in Winchester station from the vantage point of a road bridge
Debate over the meaning of the clue “One of our day walk secretaries”
“…and they're giving out free beer and bread!”
Lunch break is triggered into existence
Lunch break ends
“I'm glad we didn't do this [human pyramid] at the start of the walk”
We are now back on the high street and nearing the end of the challenge list with one and a half hours still to spare
We declare our challenge finished
Everyone has gathered in Wetherspoons. Wetherspoons is thus overfull
A record-breaking 15 minutes from the door of the house to the ticket machine outside Bournemouth station (north side)
Meanwhile, a large (huge (massive (immense (100+ people)))) group make their way from Southampton
We arrive at Lymington Pier
Subsequent train increases our numbers to 155
Most of us are still trying to get onto the ferry
On a second ferry, everyone makes it to Yarmouth
Announcement by Thomas regarding the organisation of the day
Walk begins
Compacting break at ~4.5km, which ends for some before beginning for others
Invisible sea monsters, having eaten the beaches whole, now splash us with walls of salty water 3 meters high
Lunch break in the only place where the beach was not entirely obliterated
Lunch break very precisely ends
Needles distant views
Needles slightly less distant view
A choice is made by some to take the murderous path uphill…
Thomas: That's not the way unless you're mad!
…and the murderous path is survived by all.
Tennyson Monument reached… by most
Big group photo
Another compacting break near the egg-shaped apocalypse natural aesthetica
Break ends
Axioms of fish & chips are discussed
Back in sight of Yarmouth clock tower
Walk ends
Most people take the ferry
Beautiful train change

name: The Walk with No End Part 2

checkpoints.event: Walk starts

accounts.what: Some highly inquisitive cows, actually borderline aggressive cows, nearby Durley on the Walk with No End (part 2!). We walked to Southbourne via Horndean, about 53km for Nicholas and Thomas by the end. We are somewhat worn out. Thank you to everyone who either joined us for part, or provided motivation. Or if you called us crazy- it helped!

checkpoints.event: Train taken (Southern on time!)
Second train taken
Walk begins
That hill!
Emerge on a road
Philosophical transactions by the “How the Devil's Punch Bowl got its name” panel, followed by “Which way is north” debate
Serena: I found a bog!!! This is an actual hillwalk now!
Lunch break
We observe the Devil's Punch Bowl Valley from a vantage point
We find ourselves back on a road where we were previously following a loop-o-lost navigation error
Royal School of Haslemere
Walk ends at the Station House – potentially the fanciest pub we've ever ended up in at the end of a walk this year, and stayed.
Walk starts
Walk begins
Charity bookshop calamity
We already got lost because Richard forgot the map on the train
Target practice
Send nudes
More target practice
Send more nudes
Off the beach. Finally some silence!
Lunch stop at Needles Eyed Café
Nan brings me a glass of nothing. “Exactly as you ordered.”
Richard: All I want to do now is put my head on this table and dose off.
((Very) long) lunch break ends
PoundStore calamity
Walk ends at New Milton station
Dinner for 3 at Subway (London Rd)
Walk begins with 28 people
We lost 22 people already! No, they're just way behind.
Thomas has to speak with the person with the taxi. Yes, there is someone catching up with us by taxi.
Richard: We have to stop here, 'cause I already see people half a mile back.
Tim joins via taxi
Flip a coin to decide which way to go
We open a gate and walk into an area protected from deer. There is no gate on the other side. We turn back.
Katawaredoki – sky looks beautiful
Sitting-down break, but not many listen to the advice of sitting down
Still Katawaredoki? Sky looks even beautifuller (is that a word?)
We don't want to reach Brockenhurst station too little after the 22:42 train, so we decide to take a fucking break and stargaze despite thick clouds
Me and 3 others, at the very front, fail to seek directions from the man with the map and take a wrong turn (or should I say lack of a turn)
We realise the others are no longer behind us, check some electronic maps, and start doubling back at faster pace
We're back at the point of failure and now take the correct turn
We run
We stop running
We almost take another wrong turn. I pray to God I'm remembering the train time wrong (spoiler alert, I'm not)
Meanwhile, 3 people make it to the station in time, by running the final stretch. One of them is Thomas, who nobly allows the train to pass, awaiting the rest of us
A further 12 people arrive at the station

Ahead of the other 3 from the now tailing group, I reach the last stretch of road and start running like crazy, oblivious to the fact that the train has already left (my internet won't connect to let me find that fact out)
A further 10 people arrive at the station and some start taking taxis back to Southampton

I emerge from the forest right by the station and level crossing just as the penultimate train to Poole pulls in. I cross the bridge and see in horror the panel on the platform towards Southampton showing no next train; then I'm surprised to see some of our people on the north side of the station
Final 3 people arrive. We get into taxis, except for Thomas and 2 others who decide an extra 4 hours' walk to Southampton would be nice for some reason.
Arriving at Central Station, we fumble about for cash and debate continuing home by taxi, pondering the cost
Magical U1E appears! Walk ends. Turns out even Thomas didn't walk after all.

accounts.what: We got a lot more people for this walk than we would for normal day walks during term time!

checkpoints.event: Walk begins
Dog in the way, answer 3 questions
Fig roll break
Stylish stile
Brown
Wiltshire Regiment badge
We are attacked by a living poltergate
Lunch break
Wardour Castle
where we meet 2 train missers
New Wardour Castle
Discount Playzone social / schoolyard
Nettles are so tall and dense and widespread I can't even fini
Walk ends in central Tisbury

accounts.what: “Sightseeing tour guide” has never been in the job description of the Day Walk Secretary; however, I welcome the addition. People who don't understand hiking for the sake of hiking often ask “What did you see?” So with some landmark discussion we can answer those questions, and talk about the walk to non-walkers.

checkpoints.event: We depart from the uni
On the motorway we encounter a Harry-Potter-style bus carrying plants
Unfortunate woman waves us down for petrol or for directions to the nearest petrol station, of which we can offer neither
What stranger road signs could you encounter than:
“Sudden gunfire”
“Tanks crossing”
Reach Lulworth car park
Groups organisation: a short/medium group of 27 (myself included) and a long group of 19. Thus we start walking
At the small Lulworth Cove beach we backtrack and pick a different path uphill
Break in the fog; draw distance 30m
Dog heads towards a water recipient but instead of just drinking jumps in.
Lee: That is a metaphor for my life right now

Reaching a street, somebody has the impression that there should be 28 in our group and we are missing a person. We repeatedly count 27 heads. But according to the above we're supposed to be 27, and on that observation we resume walking.
Break
Vote to continue pushing forward rather than have lunch in thick clouds by a massive pile of horse shit
Break
Lunch break, still in the clouds
Lunch break ends
Break
Break before what we think to be the final descent before Durdle Door
We progress through the fog and an extraneous hill is revealed which we had forgotten about
We meet the long group above Durdle Door beach, which they'd already been to. A whole bunch then split in search for toilets, while the remaining long group start walking a final loop.
Gone swimming
Everyone reunites on the beach
Group picture with the arch
Izzy calls names from the list to ensure everyone is present. Then we leave the beach for the final stretch towards the fish&chips shop
Fish&chips
Minibus 2 leaves car park
Minibus 2 arrives at Highfield Interchange
Walk begins
A tired rough-nighter contemplates the possibility to give up the walk, but soon changes his mind
Most open field ever
Bentley Wood signpost crossroads
We encounter Hook & Glove pub
We got bitten while sitting in Pitton
Lunch break opposite the Silver Plough pub
Lunch break ends
We get directionally misplaced and take a detour (no we're NOT lost!) and thus see a deer
Panel: Danger! Deer stalking, keep out
Richard: So that deer was stalking us!
Clarendon Palace Royal Court ruins. Rest break. Thomas water-fans the sleepers.
Great spire in the sky
Walk ends
Walk stars
Consecutive tunnels
A comprehensive discussion on junction choices
Overly long toilet break in vicinity of pubs; we suspect the toiletees stopped for a pint and left us to dry out in the sun
Two cars come from opposite directions on this narrow road and meet exactly, but exactly, where we're standing
Lunch break by a very conveniently placed ice cream shop
Lunch break ends
Richard: Are we going through the trees?
Thomas: No, we're just waiting in the shade.
John beats the record of how late in the afternoon he gets someone to reply 'Good morning' to his greeting 'Good morning'
A moment of confusion in memory of the once-not-so-packed pubs
Walk ends at Crown & Anchor

accounts.what: I am astounded by the ambition that a few fellow hikers can spend on something so inconsequential as getting strangers to reply 'Good morning' when it's no longer morning. Just after 12pm it was funny; at 2pm it started to be concerning; at 4pm it became downright unfathomable.

checkpoints.event: Walk begins
Lunch break
Lunch break ends
Giant Sequoia
Walk ends
Minibus 2 set off
Sam drives the minibus as she would a rollercoaster, and I mean that in a good way
Shaun's playlist for the first leg of the journey deserves a qual-o-meter of 100%
The man that can't be moved
What's the opposite of quick? Common people would say slow. We hillwalkers say scenic. Isn't it amazing how we manage to see the bright side of everything, even satnavs with less than ideal settings.
Minibus 1 arrives at first M6 services, where we shall have a McDonald's excuse of a dinner (well, all but the most self-respectful of us)
Minibus 2 arrives at first M6 services
Minibus 1 leaves services
Minibus 2 leaves services
Now Roger drives minibus 2 and Shaun's playlist is still going. I cannot really comment on the driving as it's all straight flat motorway. Music qual-o-meter for this leg of the journey: 84%
Minibus 1 arrives at subsequent services
Minibus 2 arrives at subsequent services
Both minibuses leave services
Shaun now drives through the more difficult section of the journey, his playlist presumably still going. Unfortunately I fall asleep again and therefore cannot comment on these facts.
Minibus 2 arrives at accommodation: Windermere Chalet
Minibus 1 arrives at accommodation
Lights off
I get up
Breakfast starts being served
Breakfast stops being served
Briefing for “a prompt 08:30 departure”
We split into a “challenging” group of 11, led by Byron, and a “less challenging” (fun?) group of 15, led by Serena
Minibus 1 (the “challenging” group) leaves for Swirrel Edge
After much manoeuvre, minibus 1 manages to pull out of the car park and actually depart
After much fiddling with satnavs, minibus 1 really actually truly starts moving
Driving hardcore level 1000: How to overtake a streak of 8 cyclists with a minibus on a narrow, snakey-ass road
Roof rack containers start coming loose and rattling against the window, so we pull over and take them down before they completely fly off
We (the challenging group) arrive into a relevant car park
Begin march of approach
Begin effective climb
Breath-catch at a significant checkpoint
Stop on a pile of rocks from where we can see the summit
Split of edges: 5 of us (Roger, Hoy, Thomas & Maurice & Nick) form an even more challenging group, taking left towards Striding edge
We (the slightly less challenging group) emerge onto the plateau at alternative summit 1, namely a rock pile
Woosh past trig point, which might be the official summit
Why would there be a cycle up here, let alone a dozen?!
The challenging group rejoin at alternative summit 2, namely a stick
We establish radio contact with the fun group and they report having stopped for lunch and to attend to an asthma inconvenience. We ourselves stop for lunch
(Semi)group photo by the stick
Meanwhile the fun group report being able to see us over the valley. It's cold and we decide not to wait for them
Now it's suddenly sunny and we stop for reciprocal photo service by the trig point
Begin descent
Wind… Stahp!
Fun group radio us as they have lost 3 people who walked ahead. They immediately find them
Tail of challenging group reaches minibus
Brief shopping
We arrive at accommodation
Byron: Hmmm… Serena has the key.
Everyone: (Most desolated exclamation ever)
Teo: If you have a hairpin we can probably lockpick this.
Nick: I may not have a hairpin, but I do have a boot!
Byron brings bleak news about the fun group, so we need to
get dinner started ahead of their arrival, but for that we need proper knives, for which we must pay a deposit,
towards which I lend him £10 to give the manager
Wild Serena appears, soon followed by the entire fun group
Dinner is served; food qual-o-meter reads 99%
We have acquired a table of 12 people of which none is strictly English
By this time a vast majority of us has gone to sleep
I get up; immediately I see breakfast going on
Pack up etc
We encounter a slight paradox in terms of people and bags distribution
Minibuses move
We reach the car park by Coniston visitor centre
Tom realises his rucksack is missing
After searching all minibus roof storages, we wager there was a mixup with another large group packing their vans next to us leading to Tom's rucksack being misplaced
Serena rings the bunkhouse and asks about the rucksack
Bunkhouse calls back and says it's been found
We split into a challenging group (led by Byron), a mid-speed group (led by Serena), and a Lakes group (led by Tom); the latter will detour back to the bunkhouse to recover the lost rucksack
The challenging group (13 people) escape pavement into nature. The road is already scrambly despite being nowhere near a mountain top yet
We reach a most infamous–looking rubble area (old quarry buildings), where 3–way contact is established and Byron persuades Manuel to wait for Serena's group
Lunch break on some big rocks by a lake (this being the Lake District, such a location label is quite useless)
Summit
Being descent, longer route
Respiro by Goats' Water (lake). Serena is not reachable by radio. We spot some brave climbers on the nearly vertical rock face opposite and attempt to zoom in on them with various cameras.
Back into the town, we reach out to the other teams; seeing they're all still hiking, we have a free choice of pub to wait for them in and so choose the Crown Inn
Team Lakes arrive at the pub
We leave the pub
Team middle start gathering by the minibuses
Minibus 2 leaves
Minibus race on the motorway (insurance companies don't read this!)
Sam keeps driving
We stop in Chester to have dinner at the George Wetherspoon
Table 34 is the most eventful dinner table in a decade
We all leave Whetherspoon
On this leg of the journey, Roger drives, and Shaun's playlist suffers a momentary Disney shift
We exit the motorway for a final break and driver swap
Byron: I don't think Serena and the others will stop here, because they missed the turn at the roundabout and ended up back on the motorway.
Back on the road
Shaun drives the final stretch, which will be the more daunting one because of people being dropped off at their doors. Music qual-o-meter for the whole journey back: 88%
Refuel
Drop off Glen Eyre
Drop off Cantell School roundabout
Drop off Mayfield road
Drop off City Gateway
Drop off Wessex Lane. I am hereby no longer aware of the whereabouts of the minibus
Begin walk
James: Should we look for a path or should we go cross-country?… Let's go cross-country!
Teo: Platform Grass for the 9:50 CrossCountry service to the Next Path. Calling at Next Path only.
A man sets us up for the bogs
Horses in the field
Serena: They won't talk to me!
Teo: Even though they know perfect English?
As we enter Lyndhurst on a narrow-ass sidewalk, a lorry speeds around a bend in the road, tilts over, and pushes us towards a high wall, allowing about 20cm on either side of our heads
Lunch around toilets building
Head to chocolate fair
Caution! Child throwing tantrum across path.
After much toilet-disfunctionality-related kerfuffle, we leave Lyndhurst centre
We reach the renowned Green Area on the edge of Brockenhurst
Walk ends

I (Teo) should be employed with trains – people claim – because not only can I near-perfectly immitate platform announcements, but I also know to pull open a door which seems unwilling to slide open by itself.

name: Unofficial Official West Sussex day walk

checkpoints.event: We get on platform 2 for the 9:32 Southern train towards London Victoria. Platform panel says “Terminates here”. We look at the closed doors reluctantly and the platform attendant tells us to walk in.
We find seats and get comfortable.
In-train announcement says that “this train is no longer in public service.” We disappointedly get off. Meanwhile, platform panel says “9:32 London Victoria”

We wander aimlessly around the station; we can't completely overhaul our walk plans because of an arrangement with a member who has already gone to Chichester, earlier in the morning, for a pre-walk run
Back on platform 2, we board another train which looks suspiciously like the previous; platform panel says “10:13 Brighton”
We were supposed to start the walk, but in fact we've barley left Southampton

We'd have had 3 minutes to change in Chichester to catch the 11:14 stopping service back to Fishbourne were it not for the first train astonishingly being 2 minutes early. Richard runs across the bridge and almost boards the wrong train, which would have taken him back to Emsworth or all the way to Havant.
Walk begins from Fishbourne, 50 minutes later than it should have
We proudly notice the group has, for the first time in ages, 100% appropriate footwear

Planned walk takes a turn for the worse when a forset we were planning to cross turns out to be a fenced off conservation area. We are forced to walk on some roads and to listen to Richard incessantly say that we should have stuck to the plan regardless.
The middle of nowhere we thought this road to be going through suddenly becomes a post-modern posh villa village
We finally make it back to non-asphalt area and stop for lunch near some wooden benches on what could generously be called a beach
Lunch break ends
Teo: “This mud is so wrong! It's just unlike all the muds we've been through recently.”
“Holy crap it's a crab” as we walk over (and further smash) the shards of what used to be a living crab's shell

A certain member who shall respectfully remain unnamed repeatedly asks strangers for directions, despite there existing current and future day walk secretaries who carry maps, compasses, and a perfectly functional sense of direction

Slightly high tide means the ford over a section of Bosham channel is not trivially traversable on foot. Once again it is proven that drying one's feet/complaining/laughing about it and walking around the long (dry) way take approximately equal amounts of time.
Accidental stop by ice cream van
45° pause
Walk ends at the Barleycorn in Nutbourne after 19.6km

name: Unofficial Official Taddiford Gap Coastal Walk

checkpoints.event: Walk begins from New Milton station
We reach a roundabout much discussed on the map, but it looks like just an ordinary roundabout
Bogs (Richard receives death threats)
Dogs
Break by Milford on Sea Kiosk and beach recently cleared of warfare metalworks
Lunch break
We reach the easy side of Hurst castle

We reach the dark side of Hurst castle, which for matters of high tides requires walking a certain length of knee-deep ocean water. In spite of everybody else, I (Teo) decide to detour the whole entire rest of the castle to get on the other side of this wet and salty adventure.
It turns out parkouing all the dry contour of Hurst castle and drying one's feet/complaining about it take approximately equal amounts of time

As we walk on a half flooded road, a car comes from ahead. Despite being a car and despite the flood being on its half of the road, the car pulls over onto our side, forcing us to walk through the flood.
Art gallery in Milford on Sea
Walk ends at The Ship Inn after 23km,
but then we change our minds
and (while Matt R preorders through an app just to spite us… OK perhaps he was hungry)
we end up in Wetherspoons,
where we drink and eat and eat and drink
until we leave
and reach the station to catch the 18:29 northbound.
Minibuses set off from before the Union building
Tom drives and DJs minibus 2. Music quality on my personal, non-relatable scale: 96%
Minibus 2 arrives at Bridport and stops in a car park, then we wait for the others inside for a bit
Izzy: It's arctic winds, let's go back home!
Minibus 1 arrives.
Tom: You overtook us twice, we never overtook you, yet we arrived first!
James: Yea, we took a wrong turn…

After final map clarifications, we split into 2 groups. The fast (and longer distance covering) group, led by Byron, is formed originally of 17 people, myself (Teo) included; the slow (and fun?) group, led by Serena, is formed of 13 people. As such, we set off for the walk.
Asphalt ends and real climb begins
We (the fast group) reach the first hilltop, where there are winds! Though nothing like what's going to be waiting for us in the evening.
Izzy and Matt R fall back to the slow group (due to Izzy's purposefully very heavy rucksack that she brought for her personal training, for which we congratulate her) equalising group sizes
And we're at sea/river level again. Clearly this is Jurassic Coast Deluxe.
We reached the top of the tallest hill visible; meanwhile the slow group radio in and report having stopped on the beach (perhaps for a swim? Did I mishear that?)
We miss a clear “coastal path diversion” sign and end up in an overgrown landslide
Snow starts to settle on hat tops and lands. / Crosswinds and snowflakes at high speed draw bands / Across my vision. It looks so bizarre: / I watch my life on an old VCR.
Coffee/water & bread break (Joe is bae)
Golden Cap trig point
Golden Cap tombstone

After debating wind, temperature, and stomach conditions, we stop for lunch under the precarious protection from wind granted by bushes, dirt bumps, and the Golden Cap tombstone itself (I know it's not a tombstone but it looks awfully like one)
Lunch break ends
Significant bench stop

We hit a critical turning point from which we start heading back toward Bridport; meanwhile the slow group have just reached the Golden Cap tombstone and Serena radios out her dismay of Tom's unexemplary behaviour of standing up on the Golden Cap trig point
Stanton St Gabriel
Along a flooded muddy road, attempting to bypass the bogs by holding onto the right fence and climbing on the side,
we catch up with the slow group, who have just reached safe terrain after the same muddy manoeuvre
and are now attending a barbed wire first aid event
but we steam past as we have no sense of compassion

Merging back into the outbound path, we stop halfway up a hill on a bench for a water break. Looking back we see the slow group and notice they're not making much progress. We ask them if everything is fine and they radio back informing us of their in progress biscuit break
We're half a mile from the town according to a signpost, while the slow group report being half an hour behind us
We reach the town seafront asphalt street
In front of The George pub, we employ my mud brush to prevent catastrophic damage to the pub's carpets
We take seats in the pub, having walked 25.5 km according to Richard's distance tracker
Pints of Thatcher's and other beverages fly onto our table; my face is burning red from the sudden change in temperature and airflow conditions
The fast part of the slow group, consisting of 9 people, arrive at the pub

accounts.what: The stranded minibus situation! Minibus 2&3 turned off the A5 for some reason (According to minibus 2, turn off was due to navigation error with Arshad using a map not a satnav). Whilst going up a hill, minibus 3 starts to get clutch problems. Minibus 2 makes it up the hill, minibus 3 decides clutch is fucked, hill ahead is far too steep, try and turn around. Through some witchcraft, minibus 3 ends up with front against a stone wall and rear wheels stuck in mud. After adding stones to try and provide extra traction and not succeeding, minibus 2 is despatched to the bottom of the hill to collect 3’s passengers. Minibus 3’s passengers hike 1km to minibus 2 and get back to bunkhouses safely. Minibus 3 is now left stranded awaiting assistance. After a very long wait, and a lack of decent communication from the RAC, the recovery vehicle arrives. Defender 90 equipped with winch, snorkel, and all manner of gadgets in the back. After a failed attempt with traction mats, and a failed attempt to squeeze the defender around the rear of the minibus, we begin to debate the feasibility of winching the minibus to a straightened orientation. After this turns out to be futile without damaging the fence, wall or minibus, metal traction ladders are brought into play. These prove to be more effective and with the aid of 4 people pushing from the front, the minibus finally finds some grip. Under direction of the recovery guy, the minibus is eventually orientated to face up the hill, paper work is filled in and we make a move. Clutch is still dodgy but we just about make it up the hill!
